content.webTitle: Why are people flocking to take part in a flight crash simulator?

fields.headline: Why are people flocking to take part in a flight crash simulator?
fields.bodyText: I’m locked inside a shipping container next to Melbourne’s Yarra River and I’m thinking about plummeting into the Pacific Ocean. It’s a beautiful day outside but it’s pitch black inside this steel box. Metal is screeching overhead as a flight attendant softly tells me I’m going to die. This is Flight, the latest immersive theatre work/public panic attack from UK group Darkfield. Audiences are strapped into 20 or so seats from a decommissioned plane and experience the work through binaural headphones in the dark. Over the course of 30 minutes you live through two surreal and intersecting realities: one where the plane lands and another that’s not so lucky. The show is in Melbourne for one more week and people are frantically tagging their mates on Instagram: “We need to do this!!” A young woman asks: “Does it involve getting kidnapped?” Her friend replies: “If you’re lucky!!” Only one of these comments – posted on a video of Blair Witch-style flickering cabin lights – feels true to my experience: “Jesus Christ”. I’m not the ideal audience member for this work – or, in a weird way, maybe I am? I write the contents of this show every time I set foot on a plane. I imagine each thing that could go wrong and analyse the noises and studiously count the seats to my nearest exit. I have exercises to cope with the anxiety. Unfortunately, the first step is often closing my eyes, to centre and stabilise myself – but this isn’t helpful inside a plane that’s plunged into darkness. Still, I’ve felt much safer on 15-hour international flights than I felt during the 30 minutes inside this stationary shipping container sitting 50 metres from the Southbank Macca’s. People have always wanted to experience or understand the extremes of this world (think Greek tragedies and “freak shows”), but there is something very 2019 about knowingly paying a dollar a minute to take part in a plane crash. This is an age of climate crisis and murder podcasts and people begging Timothée Chalamet to run you over with his car. With rolling doomsday updates in our pockets at all times, we’ve never been more exposed to the spectre of death. We’re all more desensitised to it and some of us are looking for small ways to conquer it. Fear also has a visceral appeal. Explaining the enduring appeal of haunted houses, sociologist Margee Kerr told the Atlantic “it’s all about triggering the amazing fight-or-flight response to experience the flood of adrenaline, endorphins and dopamine”. When this is done in a space the mind rationally recognises as safe, “we are often left feeling satisfied, reassured of our safety and more confident in our ability to confront the things that initially scared us”. The creatives behind Flight are happy to compare their work to haunted houses. Darkfield describes itself as “a multisensory sonic theme park” and boasts that its shows will “steal you from reality”. The first work it released in 2017 was a “spine-tingling” seance ripped straight from the tradition of Victorian-era spiritualism and supercharged by modern technology. Director David Rosenberg has said the work, which is also carried out in the dark, “is a bit like a sideshow fairground ride”. Since then, more than 100,000 people have attended Darkfield works across the UK, Australia and Mexico. Flight is the second show from the company, and the third is called Coma (it’s exactly what it sounds like). It’s often been said these shows – Flight included – are not “substantial enough” as works of theatre; that the physical thrill is impressive but empty of meaning. One reviewer described Coma as “a scary movie without a message”. For what it’s worth, Flight does try to hint at more: it’s loosely concerned with parallel universes and has passing references to Schrödinger. But that’s not why people are rushing out to lock themselves in this steel box. My friend doesn’t do too badly on planes, but she does suffer from anxiety too. We often confess our fears to each other about money, relationships, ageing, the environment, work, social media, family, health, housing – all of it. Some are irrational, others not so much. I asked her why she agreed to come along to Flight and she replied: “I’m terrified of dying, but I also want to know what it’s like to die.” After the terror, as I stepped into the sun, I did feel a sense of twisted comfort. The fear was all for nothing. Actually, right now, in this moment, I’m OK. I can’t say I recommend it, but I think I understand the appeal. • Flight is in Southbank, Melbourne until 8 December
